questions.text: A 64 year old man has had a 6 month history of progressive worsening of confusion. He had left the cooker on several times and accused the neighbours of spying on him. On examination, his face is expressionless and he has a monotonous speech. Cranial nerves are normal. Increased tone is present in all 4 limbs. Reflexes, power and sensation are all normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with features of parkinsonism (expressionless face, monotonous speech, increased tone in all four limbs, suggesting bradykinesia and rigidity), combined with a relatively short history (6 months) of significant cognitive decline (worsening confusion, leaving cooker on) and psychiatric symptoms (delusions of being spied on).
  • This constellation of symptoms, particularly the co-occurrence of parkinsonism and early cognitive/psychiatric features, strongly points to Lewy body dementia.
  • In Lewy body dementia, cognitive fluctuations, hallucinations, and parkinsonian features often present relatively early in the disease course, and parkinsonism can precede or occur concurrently with cognitive decline.

Explanation of Other Options:

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Parkinson's disease primarily presents with motor symptoms first (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), and while dementia can occur, it typically develops in long-standing disease (Parkinson's disease dementia), usually much later than 6 months into the illness. The prominent early confusion and delusions make Lewy body dementia more likely in this case.

Alzheimer's dementia (Option C): Alzheimer's dementia typically presents with memory impairment as the prominent initial symptom, followed by other cognitive deficits. It does not typically present with parkinsonian features or prominent delusions/hallucinations early in the disease course.

Huntington's chorea (Option D): Huntington's chorea is characterized by involuntary choreiform movements, cognitive decline (often with executive dysfunction), and psychiatric symptoms. The patient's presentation of rigidity and bradykinesia (increased tone, expressionless face, monotonous speech) is inconsistent with the typical hyperkinetic movements of Huntington's chorea.

Key Takeaway:

The co-occurrence of parkinsonism, progressive cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms like delusions, especially with an early onset of cognitive issues relative to motor symptoms, is highly suggestive of Lewy body dementia.

questions.text: A 34 year old man has bradykinesia and rigidity of his limb movements. He was also noticed to have choreiform movements when observed. He has a history of poor development during the latter part of school education. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a combination of bradykinesia and rigidity (parkinsonian features), along with choreiform movements, and a history of poor development during school education (suggesting cognitive/developmental issues). This blend of symptoms is highly characteristic of Huntington's disease.
  • In Huntington's disease, as the disease progresses, chorea often coexists with, and can eventually be replaced by, dystonia and parkinsonian features such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. It is also associated with cognitive impairment and psychiatric manifestations.

Explanation of Other Options:

New variant CJD (Option A): New variant CJD presents differently, typically with rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.

Parkinson's disease (Option B): Parkinson's disease is primarily characterized by parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor) but is not associated with chorea.

Alzheimer's disease (Option C): Alzheimer's disease presents differently, mainly as memory impairment and typically in an older age group, and it does not involve choreiform movements or prominent parkinsonian features.

Key Takeaway:

The co-occurrence of choreiform movements with parkinsonian features (bradykinesia, rigidity) and cognitive/developmental impairment in a younger adult strongly indicates Huntington's disease.

questions.text: A 19-year old man has difficulty walking. He has had problems with vision which were difficult to correct with glasses. On examination, there is nystagmus and pallor of the optic discs. He has dysarthria and intention tremors. There are absent reflexes in the knees and ankles. Plantars are equivocal. Pes cavus was noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a classic combination of symptoms: difficulty walking (ataxia), vision problems (difficult to correct with glasses, optic disc pallor), nystagmus, dysarthria, intention tremors (cerebellar signs), absent deep tendon reflexes (knees and ankles), and pes cavus. This constellation of findings, particularly the presence of both cerebellar signs and absent reflexes, along with pes cavus, is highly indicative of Friedreich's Ataxia.
  • Friedreich's Ataxia is an autosomal recessively inherited disorder. Neurological abnormalities include optic atrophy (consistent with optic disc pallor) and retinitis pigmentosa, nystagmus, cerebellar disease and signs, loss of dorsal column sensation, and weakness. Pes cavus (high arched feet) is usually present. Patients may also have cardiomyopathy and diabetes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Spinocerebellar ataxia (Option A): Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is an autosomal dominant ataxia. While it causes cerebellar signs, the specific combination of absent reflexes and pes cavus as seen here is less characteristic of SCAs in general compared to Friedreich's ataxia. SCA7 is associated with blue-yellow color blindness, but the overall clinical picture here is more consistent with Friedreich's.

Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration (Option C): Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration primarily affects the cerebellum, causing ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus. However, it typically does not cause absent reflexes (neuropathy) or pes cavus, and it would generally be seen in the context of chronic heavy alcohol abuse.

Wilson's disease (Option D): Wilson's disease presents differently, typically with parkinsonian features, dystonia, and characteristic Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings in the cornea (not the lens). It is not associated with pes cavus.

Key Takeaway: The combination of cerebellar ataxia (difficulty walking, dysarthria, intention tremor, nystagmus), optic atrophy, absent deep tendon reflexes, and pes cavus is a classic presentation of Friedreich's Ataxia.

questions.text: A 31 year old man had a progressive four month history of stiffness, tremors and unsteadiness. There is no family history of a similar problem. On examination, there is a globally increased tone. Power is normal and there are brisk reflexes throughout. A resting tremor and some abnormal writhing movements in the arms were observed. He has an MMSE score of 25/30. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a subacute (four-month) history of progressive stiffness, tremors (including resting tremor), and unsteadiness, along with globally increased tone, brisk reflexes, and abnormal writhing (choreiform) movements in the arms. He also shows cognitive impairment (MMSE 25/30).
  • This combination of parkinsonian features (stiffness, resting tremor), dystonia/choreiform movements, and cognitive impairment, particularly in a young adult, is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease.
  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that can present with a wide range of neurological (including movement disorders like chorea, dystonia, parkinsonism) and psychiatric symptoms, often accompanied by cognitive decline.
  • Other conditions like neuroacanthocytosis, Huntington's, and paraneoplastic syndrome can also present with choreiform movements and cognitive impairment.
  • Zinc is used for treatment of Wilson disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Motor neuron disease (Option A): Motor neuron disease presents differently, primarily with progressive weakness, muscle wasting, fasciculations, and upper motor neuron signs (brisk reflexes) but lacks the prominent tremor, rigidity, and choreiform movements seen here.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (Option B): Polymyalgia rheumatica presents differently, characterized by muscle pain and stiffness, predominantly in the shoulders and hips, often with elevated inflammatory markers, and does not cause tremors, rigidity, choreiform movements, or cognitive impairment.

Friedrich's ataxia (Option C): Friedrich's ataxia presents differently, primarily with cerebellar signs (ataxia, dysarthria, intention tremor), optic atrophy, absent deep tendon reflexes, and pes cavus. While unsteadiness and some tremor can occur, the prominent rigidity, resting tremor, and writhing movements, along with brisk reflexes, are less typical for Friedreich's ataxia.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of parkinsonian features (stiffness, resting tremor), dystonia/choreiform movements, and cognitive impairment in a young adult strongly points towards Wilson's disease, a treatable genetic disorder of copper metabolism.

questions.text: A 68 year old man has early signs of cognitive impairment. His wife describes urinary incontinence and unsteadiness on walking in the past six months. Examination reveals ataxia and he has an MTS score of 7/10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient, a 68-year-old man, presents with a classic triad of symptoms: cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, and unsteadiness on walking (ataxia). This "triad" is highly characteristic of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH).
  • In NPH, there is ventricular enlargement on CT scan that is out of proportion to brain atrophy. Surgical CSF shunting remains the main treatment modality, as symptoms can be reversible with timely intervention.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lewy body disease (Option A): Lewy body disease presents differently, typically with early fluctuating cognition, recurrent visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While cognitive impairment and unsteadiness can occur, urinary incontinence is less of a prominent early feature compared to NPH.

Alzheimer's dementia (Option B): Alzheimer's dementia presents differently, primarily with progressive memory impairment, often without the early prominent gait disturbance or urinary incontinence seen in NPH.

Creutzfeldt Jakob disease (Option C): Creutzfeldt Jakob disease presents differently, characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, often with prominent myoclonus and cerebellar ataxia, and a much faster progression than described here.

Key Takeaway: The classic triad of cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, and gait disturbance (ataxia) in an elderly patient strongly suggests Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus, a potentially treatable condition.

questions.text: A 47 year old man was referred for assessment of unsteady gait, which has been present for 6 months. He has lost a stone in weight over the several months. An MRI of the brain shows multiple high signal areas. A biopsy was taken of one of the lesions. The report shows perivascular infiltrates of lymphocytes affecting white and gray matter. There was minimal myelin loss. CSF examination shows raised white cell count, and oligoclonal bands were not raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with progressive neurological symptoms (unsteady gait), systemic symptoms (weight loss), multiple brain lesions on MRI, and a biopsy showing perivascular infiltrates of lymphocytes affecting both white and gray matter with minimal myelin loss. The CSF shows a raised white cell count but absent oligoclonal bands.
  • The presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, combined with diffuse lymphocytic infiltrates affecting both white and gray matter on biopsy, strongly suggests CNS lymphoma. While multiple sclerosis (MS) can also show lymphocytic infiltrates, the weight loss and the involvement of both white and gray matter are more indicative of lymphoma. Also, while oligoclonal bands can be absent in a small percentage of MS patients, their absence combined with other features points away from MS as the most likely diagnosis in this context.

Explanation of Other Options:

Creutzfeldt Jakob disease (Option A): Creutzfeldt Jakob disease presents differently, typically with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and characteristic MRI changes (e.g., restricted diffusion) but not lymphocytic infiltrates or weight loss as primary features.

Progressive multifocal leucoencephalopathy (Option B): Progressive multifocal leucoencephalopathy (PML) presents differently, typically with demyelinating lesions caused by JC virus in immunocompromised patients, and biopsy would show oligodendrocyte abnormalities and viral inclusions, not primary lymphocytic infiltrates.

Glioma (Option D): Glioma presents differently; it is a primary brain tumor that would show atypical glial cells on biopsy, often with significant mass effect and contrast enhancement, rather than perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates.

Key Takeaway:

In a patient with progressive neurological symptoms, systemic constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss), multiple brain lesions on MRI, and a biopsy showing perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates affecting both white and gray matter, CNS lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 31 year old man complains of spasms in his neck. He has, over the past three years, noticed a crampy sensation in his neck associated with contraction of the muscle on the left. This has now become frequent and uncontrollable. Neurological examination is normal, but on tapping the left side of the neck muscle, it contracts and spasms occur. Which of the following medications may help this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a history of involuntary, crampy muscle contractions and spasms in the neck, which have become frequent and uncontrollable, indicating dystonia. The normal neurological examination, apart from the muscle contractions, supports a primary movement disorder.
  • Levodopa is a medication that may help with dystonia. While often associated with Parkinson's disease, levodopa-responsive dystonia is a known condition. In severe cases of dystonia, botulinum toxin injections may also be used. Diazepam can also be helpful.

Explanation of Other Options:

Phenytoin (Option B): Phenytoin presents differently; it is an antiepileptic drug primarily used for seizure disorders, and it is not indicated for the treatment of dystonia.

Lamotrigine (Option C): Lamotrigine presents differently; it is an antiepileptic drug used for seizures and bipolar disorder, and it is not a primary treatment for dystonia.

Methyldopa (Option D): Methyldopa presents differently; it is an antihypertensive medication and is not used to treat dystonia.

Key Takeaway: In a patient presenting with dystonia, characterized by involuntary, sustained muscle contractions causing spasms, medications like levodopa or diazepam may be helpful, and in severe cases, botulinum toxin injections are an option.

questions.text: A 68 year old man presents with a history of falls. He has difficulty reading and walking down stairs. He has dysarthria, akinesia and rigidity. Power of the muscles is normal, reflexes are brisk. What physical sign will help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including parkinsonian features (akinesia, rigidity) and a history of falls, difficulty reading, and walking down stairs, is highly suggestive of Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP).
  • PSP is characterized by a combination of parkinsonian features and a gaze palsy. Therefore, the physical sign that will help confirm the diagnosis is the demonstration of impairment of voluntary eye movements, particularly vertical gaze, which is a classic feature of the disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gait (Option A): Gait is a symptom of PSP, as evidenced by the patient's history of falls and unsteadiness.

Romberg's sign (Option C): Romberg's sign assesses proprioception and vestibular function and is not the key diagnostic sign for this disorder.

Abdominal reflexes (Option D): Abdominal reflexes are not relevant to the diagnosis of PSP.

Key Takeaway:

The co-occurrence of parkinsonian features with a history of falls and a supranuclear gaze palsy (impaired voluntary eye movements) is a key diagnostic feature of Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP).

questions.text: A 65 years old man has had longstanding tremors in both his hands and forearms. Examination reveals normal tone, power and reflexes in his arms. The tremors improve when he drinks alcohol. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has longstanding, bilateral tremors in his hands and forearms, which are noted to improve with alcohol intake. His neurological examination is otherwise normal, with normal tone, power, and reflexes. This clinical picture is classic for Benign essential tremor.
  • Features supporting a diagnosis of Essential Tremor:
    • Bilateral action tremor of the hands and forearms.
    • Absence of other neurological signs, except the cogwheel phenomenon.
    • May have isolated head tremor with no signs of dystonia.
    • Secondary criteria include a long disease duration (>3 years), a positive family history, and a beneficial response to alcohol.
    • Essential tremor is the commonest cause of head tremor (titubation)

Explanation of Other Options:

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Parkinson's disease presents differently, typically with a resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The tremor often does not improve with alcohol.

Motor neuron disease (Option B): Motor neuron disease presents differently, primarily with progressive weakness, muscle wasting, and fasciculations, not with a tremor as the main symptom.

Prion infection (Option D): Prion infections (e.g., CJD) present differently, typically with rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.

Key Takeaway:

A longstanding, bilateral action tremor that improves with alcohol and is the primary neurological finding in an otherwise normal examination is the hallmark of Benign essential tremor.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has an 18 month history of unsteady gait, difficulty to speak and to perform fine movements with the fingers. She has a history of moderate alcohol intake. Neurological examination showed scanning dysarthria, horizontal nystagmus in the lateral gaze, severe bilateral dysmetria in the upper and lower limbs, bilateral dysdiadochokinesis, severe gait ataxia and inability to maintain the sitting. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a constellation of signs, including unsteady gait (ataxia), difficulty speaking (scanning dysarthria), and difficulty with fine movements (dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesis). The examination also reveals nystagmus. This specific combination of symptoms is a classic description of cerebellar syndrome.
  • Cerebellar signs include:
    • Vertigo
    • Ataxia
    • Nystagmus
    • Intention tremor
    • Scanning speech
    • Hypotonia
    • Dysdiadochokinesis
  • Cerebellar syndromes can be caused by various factors, including alcohol, space-occupying lesions, multiple sclerosis, and inherited syndromes. The patient's history of moderate alcohol intake is a common cause for this presentation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Parkinson's disease presents differently, primarily with a resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity, and lacks the pronounced cerebellar signs like scanning dysarthria and dysmetria.

Subacute combined degeneration (Option B): Subacute combined degeneration presents differently, typically with demyelination of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord, leading to a mix of sensory ataxia, weakness, and brisk reflexes, but not the classic cerebellar signs described here.

Motor neuron disease (Option D): Motor neuron disease presents differently, primarily with progressive weakness, muscle wasting, and fasciculations, with no cerebellar signs.

Key Takeaway: A clinical picture dominated by ataxia (gait, trunk), dysarthria, nystagmus, and dysdiadochokinesis is the hallmark of a cerebellar syndrome, which has several potential etiologies.

questions.text: A 64 year old man presents with difficulty with his mobility. He has increased tone, bradykinesia, a pill rolling tremor and a shuffling gait. Which medication should be commenced first?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with increased tone, bradykinesia, a pill-rolling tremor, and a shuffling gait is a classic clinical picture of Parkinson's disease.
  • Co-careldopa is the first-line medication of choice for symptomatic treatment. It is a combination of L-Dopa and Carbidopa, which works to increase dopaminergic activity in the basal ganglia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Benztropine (Option A): Benztropine is an anticholinergic used for specific side effects.

Amantadine (Option B): Amantadine is an antiviral and a second-line drug for Parkinson's disease.

Selegiline (Option C): Selegiline is an MAO inhibitor and a second-line drug.

Key Takeaway:

For the symptomatic treatment of Parkinson's disease, Co-careldopa is the first-line medication used to replace dopamine, while other agents are typically reserved for second-line therapy or for managing specific symptoms or side effects.

questions.text: A 72 year old woman with a history of hypertension and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus presented with a new onset of uncontrolled violent movements of the left extremities accompanied by headaches. Neurological examination was normal except for the constant, relentless, violent movement of her left arm and leg. Although she was fully awake, alert, and oriented, she could not stop the abnormal movements except for a short period of time. This presentation is likely to be due to a lesion in the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with new-onset, violent, flinging movements of her left arm and leg is a classic description of hemiballismus.
  • Hemiballismus is a rare, usually unilateral, movement disorder caused by a lesion in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus. In this case, the left-sided symptoms suggest a lesion in the right subthalamic nucleus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Substantia nigra (Option A): Lesions in the substantia nigra are primarily associated with Parkinson's disease, which presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity.

Globus pallidus (Option B): The globus pallidus is involved in a variety of movement disorders but is not the classic location for isolated hemiballismus.

Putamen (Option C): Lesions in the putamen are associated with various conditions, including Huntington's disease, but are not the primary cause of hemiballismus.

Key Takeaway:

Hemiballismus, a disorder characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements of the limbs, is most often caused by a lesion in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man comes to the clinic with his wife. He has been suffering from increasingly frequent falls and now has marked problems with his mobility. Past history of note includes an inferior MI and TIA a few years earlier. He has also suffered from two episodes of urinary retention and now has an indwelling catheter. On examination his BP is 142/72 mmHg, with a postural drop of 30 mmHg on standing. He has a quiet ejection systolic murmur, his chest is clear, and abdominal examination is unremarkable. Neurological examination reveals cogwheel rigidity and bradykinesia. He has a mild tremor only. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with parkinsonian features (cogwheel rigidity, bradykinesia, mild tremor) combined with pronounced autonomic dysfunction, specifically postural hypotension (a 30 mmHg drop) and urinary retention. This combination is highly suggestive of Multi-system atrophy (MSA).
  • The parkinsonian symptoms associated with MSA often respond poorly to dopamine agonists or L-dopa, in contrast to idiopathic Parkinson's. The tremor in MSA is also often less pronounced than in a patient with idiopathic Parkinson's.

Explanation of Other Options:

Idiopathic parkinsonism (Option A): This presents with parkinsonian features but usually with a more prominent tremor and lacks the significant early autonomic dysfunction seen here.

Lewy body disease (Option B): This presents with prominent early cognitive symptoms and visual hallucinations in addition to parkinsonian features.

Multi-infarct disease (Option C): This can cause vascular parkinsonism and cognitive impairment but typically does not cause such a pronounced degree of autonomic dysfunction.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of parkinsonism and significant autonomic dysfunction (postural hypotension and urinary retention) is the hallmark of Multi-system Atrophy, differentiating it from idiopathic Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has a monotonous, slurred speech. He has an expressionless face and a festinant gait. There is also impairment of vertical gaze. What is the most likely underlying aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with parkinsonian features (monotonous, slurred speech, expressionless face, festinant gait) combined with a key distinguishing sign: impairment of vertical gaze. This combination is a classic presentation of Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, which is also known as Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP).
  • This syndrome is also associated with pyramidal signs, dementia, or frontal lobe syndrome. The response to L-dopa is typically poor, and the median survival is about seven years.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cerebrovascular disease (Option A): This presents with a different etiology than the one described here, which is a specific neurodegenerative syndrome.

Idiopathic (Option B): This is a generic term for a disease of unknown cause and does not specifically describe this syndrome, which has a specific name and pathology.

Shy-Drager syndrome (Option C): This is a subtype of Multi-system Atrophy (MSA) and presents differently, primarily with autonomic dysfunction and postural hypotension.

Key Takeaway: The combination of parkinsonian features with a supranuclear vertical gaze palsy is the hallmark of Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome (PSP), which has a poor response to L-dopa.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is found to have absent ankle jerks and gait disturbance. Which of the following investigations is not indicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of absent ankle jerks and gait disturbance point to potential conditions like neuropathy (B12 deficiency, systemic lupus erythematosus [SLE], cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis) or dorsal root disease (tabes dorsalis).
  • Ferritin (Option D) is a measure of the body's iron stores and is not a standard investigation for the neurological conditions in this differential diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

ANA (Option A): ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) is indicated to investigate Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), which can present these neurological findings.

B12 levels (Option B): B12 levels are indicated to rule out B12 deficiency, a known cause of sensory ataxia and neuropathy.

Cholesterol levels (Option C): Cholesterol levels are relevant for investigating Cerebrotendinous Xanthomatosis, an inherited condition with gait ataxia and neuropathy that is characterized by high serum cholestanol levels.

Key Takeaway:

The differential diagnosis for absent ankle jerks and gait disturbance includes conditions like B12 deficiency, SLE, and Cerebrotendinous Xanthomatosis. Therefore, tests for B12, ANA, and cholesterol are indicated, while ferritin is not a relevant investigation in this context.

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents with weakness and reduced mobility. On examination he has a slow gait with reduced arm swing and a tremor is noticed in the left arm. Which of the following is the typical frequency of the rest tremor in Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms (slow gait, reduced arm swing, rest tremor) are consistent with Parkinson's disease.
  • The tremor of Parkinson's disease is a rest tremor with a low to moderate frequency, typically ranging from 3 to 6 Hz. Therefore, 4 Hz (Option B) is the most representative frequency among the choices.
  • Initially, the tremor is often unilateral, becoming bilateral as the disease progresses. An action tremor may also develop over time, and the tremor's severity can increase with levodopa.

Explanation of Other Options:

2 Hz (Option A): This frequency is below the typical range for a Parkinsonian rest tremor.

8 Hz (Option C): This frequency is above the typical range for a Parkinsonian rest tremor and is more characteristic of an Essential Tremor, which is a high-frequency tremor (6-10 Hz).

10 Hz (Option D): This frequency is well above the typical range for a Parkinsonian rest tremor and is also characteristic of an Essential Tremor, which is a high-frequency tremor (6-10 Hz).

Key Takeaway: The rest tremor of Parkinson's disease has a characteristic low to moderate frequency of 3 to 6 Hz, which helps to distinguish it from the high-frequency (6-10 Hz) action tremor of Essential Tremor.

Explanation:

  • Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD) is also known as Segawa syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the GCH1 gene, which is critical for dopamine biosynthesis.
  • This condition manifests as a childhood-onset dystonia with diurnal fluctuations and shows a dramatic response to low doses of levodopa.
  • It is important to recognize this condition as a possible cause of all young-onset forms of dystonia, and a trial of levodopa is recommended to rule out DRD. Parkinsonism may also be a major finding, and recessively inherited mutations can result in a more severe clinical phenotype.

Explanation of Other Options:

X linked dystonia Parkinson syndrome (Option B): This is a separate genetic disorder with distinct clinical and pathological features.

Myoclonic dystonia (Option C): This is a different movement disorder characterized by a combination of myoclonus and dystonia.

None of the above (Option D): This is incorrect as Option A is the correct answer.

Key Takeaway:

Segawa syndrome is synonymous with Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD), a genetic condition that presents in childhood and is uniquely characterized by its dramatic and sustained response to low doses of levodopa.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for restless leg syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The initial management for most RLS sufferers with mild symptoms involves general measures to improve sleep hygiene.
  • For intrusive symptoms, the treatment of choice is low doses of a dopamine agonist, such as pramipexole, ropinirole, or rotigotine, taken 1-2 hours before bedtime.
  • While levodopa may also be effective, it is more likely to be associated with augmentation (worsening of symptoms earlier in the day) or rebound effects, making dopamine agonists the preferred first choice.
  • Management of secondary RLS should be directed to correcting the underlying disorder; for example, iron replacement for anemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dopamine (Option B): The precursor, levodopa, may be effective but is associated with a higher risk of augmentation and rebound.

Haloperidol (Option C): Haloperidol is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is not used to treat RLS.

Phenytoin (Option D): Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant, and while some anticonvulsants may be effective for RLS, they are not the first-line treatment of choice.

Key Takeaway:

For intrusive symptoms of Restless Leg Syndrome, the recommended first-line treatment is low-dose dopamine agonists like pramipexole, as they are generally effective and less prone to the augmentation and rebound effects associated with levodopa.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for Huntington disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The choreatic movements characteristic of Huntington's disease are treated by reducing dopaminergic activity.
  • Tetrabenazine is a presynaptic dopamine-depleting agent and has been approved as the drug of choice for the treatment of chorea in Huntington's disease. It can, however, cause secondary parkinsonism.
  • More recently, deuterated tetrabenazine (AustedoTM) has also been approved for this indication.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dopamine (Option B): The goal of treatment is to reduce dopaminergic activity, so using dopamine would worsen the chorea.

Levodopa (Option C): Levodopa is a precursor to dopamine and is used to increase dopaminergic activity, which would exacerbate the chorea.

Riseperidone (Option D): Riseperidone is a dopamine-blocking antipsychotic that can be used to control chorea, but tetrabenazine is the specifically approved and preferred agent for this indication.

Key Takeaway:

The drug of choice for the chorea in Huntington's disease is Tetrabenazine, a presynaptic dopamine-depleting agent
